user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CountSemCreate:
```c
int32 OS_CountSemCreate(osal_id_t *sem_id, const char *sem_name, uint32 sem_initial_value, uint32 options)
{
    int32                           return_code;
    OS_object_token_t               token;
    OS_count_sem_internal_record_t *countsem;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(sem_id);
    OS_CHECK_APINAME(sem_name);

    /* Note - the common ObjectIdAllocate routine will lock the object type and leave it locked. */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew(LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_name, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        countsem = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_count_sem_table, token);

        /* Reset the table entry and save the name */
        OS_OBJECT_INIT(token, countsem, obj_name, sem_name);

        /* Now call the OS-specific implementation.  This reads info from the table. */
        return_code = OS_CountSemCreate_Impl(&token, sem_initial_value, options);

        /* Check result, finalize record, and unlock global table. */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew(return_code, &token, sem_id);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_CountSemCreate:
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char obj_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
} OS_count_sem_internal_record_t
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew(return_code, &token, sem_id);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The sem_id parameter is an output parameter (osal_id_t *sem_id) that must be written to by OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew, so it cannot be const-qualified. Similarly &token is passed to a routine that updates the token, so it must be a non-const pointer. Therefore Rule 8.13 (use const where possible) is satisfied in this call since the pointers refer to objects that are intentionally modified.
